data.title: Kobe Bryant's 10 Best Teammates, Ranked
data.meta_description: Are you wondering who Kobe Bryant's best teammates are? Check out this list of 10 who complimented the Mamba's game better than the rest!
data.text:
So, you're wondering who Kobe Bryant's best teammates are? Let's talk about it!

Kobe Bryant, one of the greatest basketball players in NBA history, had the privilege of playing alongside a diverse and talented group of teammates throughout his illustrious career which spanned two decades, primarily with the Los Angeles Lakers. There, he established himself as an iconic figure in the world of sports.

Related: Allen Iverson's Best Teammates, Ranked

Kobe's teammates played a crucial role in his journey, contributing to the team's success and helping him achieve numerous accolades. From Shaquille O'Neal to Pau Gasol, and Derek Fisher to Lamar Odom, these teammates brought their unique skills and personalities to the court, creating memorable moments and championship-winning chemistry.

Here are our picks for Kobe Bryant's best teammates:

Career Averages: 17.0 points, 9.2 rebounds, 3.2 assists

Teams: Memphis Grizzlies, Los Angeles Lakers, Chicago Bulls, San Antonio Spurs, Milwaukee Bucks

Kobe Bryant and Pau Gasol formed another highly successful and iconic partnership during their time as teammates with the Los Angeles Lakers. Their collaboration, which spanned from 2008 to 2014, was characterized by outstanding chemistry and multiple championship victories.

Kobe and Pau played a pivotal role in leading the Lakers to two NBA championships in 2009 and 2010. Their on-court synergy was instrumental in the team's success during those years. Kobe Bryant, known for his scoring ability and clutch performances, meshed perfectly with Pau Gasol's versatile skills as a big man. Pau's ability to score in the post, rebound, and pass the ball made him an ideal frontcourt partner for Kobe.

Career Averages: 8.3 points, 2.1 rebounds, 3.0 assists

Team: Los Angeles Lakers, Golden State Warriors, Utah Jazz, Oklahoma City Thunder, Dallas Mavericks

Kobe Bryant and Derek Fisher shared a special and enduring partnership as teammates on the Los Angeles Lakers for the majority of their respective careers. Their bond extended beyond the basketball court, and their collaboration contributed significantly to the Lakers' success during the 2000s.

Kobe and Derek Fisher were integral parts of five NBA championship-winning teams with the Lakers in 2000, 2001, 2002, 2009, and 2010. Their ability to perform under pressure and their leadership played crucial roles in these title runs. Both players were known for their tenacity, toughness, and leadership on the court. Fisher, in particular, was often praised for his ability to calm the team during crucial moments.

Career Averages: 13.2 points, 4.5 rebounds, 2.7 assists

Teams: Chicago Bulls, Indiana Pacers, Sacramento Kings, Houston Rockets, Los Angeles Lakers, New York Knicks

Kobe Bryant and Ron Artest, who later changed his name to Metta World Peace, shared a unique and memorable partnership during their time as teammates with the Los Angeles Lakers. Their collaboration was marked by intense defense, resilience, and a mutual commitment to winning championships.

Artest joined the Lakers during the 2009-2010 season, and his addition proved crucial in the Lakers' quest for an NBA championship. His defense and timely three-point shooting played a pivotal role in the Lakers winning the championship that year.

Career Averages: 9.6 points, 3.8 rebounds, 2.8 assists

Teams: Boston Celtics, Los Angeles Lakers

Kobe Bryant and Rick Fox were teammates on the Los Angeles Lakers during the late 1990s and early 2000s. Their partnership was marked by their contributions to the team's success, camaraderie, and their roles in some of the Lakers' most memorable moments. Kobe and Rick Fox were instrumental in helping the Lakers win three consecutive NBA championships from 2000 to 2002. Their on-court chemistry and ability to perform in high-pressure situations were crucial to the team's success.
